title: How to Treat an Outer Ear Infection

steps.title: Take over-the-counter pain medications.
steps.content: Take over-the-counter pain medications. Once you are home, you can take pain medications such as acetaminophen or ibuprofen. They should help with the pain. [2] X Trustworthy Source MedlinePlus Collection of medical information sourced from the US National Library of Medicine Go to source

steps.title: Make your own ear drop solution.
steps.content: Make your own ear drop solution. Though this treatment may not be as effective as prescription medications, you can create your own solution of saltwater or one part water to one part vinegar. Warm whichever one you chose up to body temperature before pouring it in using a bulb syringe. Let it drain out afterwards.

steps.title: Apply heat.
steps.content: Apply heat. A little heat, such as a heating pad on low or a damp washcloth heated in the microwave, can help ease pain. Hold it to your ear while you're sitting up. [3] X Research source You don't want to fall asleep on a heating pad, as you can burn yourself.

steps.title: Use over-the-counter ear drops meant for swimmer's ear.
steps.content: Use over-the-counter ear drops meant for swimmer's ear. Use these ear drops when you first notice itching. Apply them both before and after you swim. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Keep your ear dry while it is healing.
steps.content: Keep your ear dry while it is healing. You will need to keep your ear as dry as possible while you are recovering from your infection. Tilt your head away from the water even while showering. [5] X Research source

steps.title: See your doctor if you're experiencing symptoms.
steps.content: See your doctor if you're experiencing symptoms. [6] X Expert Source Monica Kieu, DO, FACS Board Certified Otolaryngologist Expert Interview. 20 October 2020. Even mild ear infections can progress quickly, so it's important to see your doctor if you have a combination of these symptoms. [7] X Trustworthy Source Centers for Disease Control and Prevention Main public health institute for the US, run by the Dept. of Health and Human Services Go to source Your doctor will likely use a special tool called an otoscope to look more closely at your ear. [8] X Trustworthy Source Johns Hopkins Medicine Official resource database of the world-leading Johns Hopkins Hospital Go to source

steps.title: Go to the emergency room or an urgent clinic.
steps.content: Go to the emergency room or an urgent clinic. If you have fever along with other symptoms or you are in a lot of pain, you should see a doctor immediately if possible. [9] X Trustworthy Source Johns Hopkins Medicine Official resource database of the world-leading Johns Hopkins Hospital Go to source

steps.title: Expect the doctor to clean your ear.
steps.content: Expect the doctor to clean your ear. Cleaning your ear allows the medicine to get where it needs to go. Your doctor may suction your ear out, or she may use an ear curette to gently scoop and scrape out your ear. [10] X Research source

steps.title: Use antibiotic drops.
steps.content: Use antibiotic drops. Your doctor will most likely write you a prescription for antibiotic drops that include neomycin. If other options don't work, your doctor might also prescribe your ciprofloxicin, which is often a second-line agent. You will then use the drops in your ear to reduce the infection. [11] X Trustworthy Source MedlinePlus Collection of medical information sourced from the US National Library of Medicine Go to source There is a very low risk of hearing loss from amino-glycosides, including neomycin. This medicine usually given in combination with polymyxin B and hydrocortisone a solution that is to be applied to the outer ear canal 4 drops 3-4 times a day as long as prescribed. Neomycin can also cause contact dermatitis. [12] X Trustworthy Source DermNet NZ Online clinical resource website written and run by dermatologists providing evidence-based information about dermatology and skin health Go to source If your ear is too blocked, you may need a wick placed in your ear, which will help deliver the drops to your ear. [13] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source To use the ear drops, warm up the bottle in your hand first. The easiest way to put them in is to tilt your head to the side or lie down. Lie on your side for 5 minutes or place a cotton ball over ear canal. [14] X Trustworthy Source National Health Service (UK) Public healthcare system of the UK Go to source Do not touch the dropper or tip to your ear or any other surface, as that can contaminate the liquid. If you have trouble getting them in the right place, ask someone to help you.

steps.title: Ask about acetic acid drops.
steps.content: Ask about acetic acid drops. Your doctor may also prescribe acetic acid drops, which are a form of vinegar. [15] X Trustworthy Source MedlinePlus Collection of medical information sourced from the US National Library of Medicine Go to source However, they are stronger than your average household vinegar. These drops help recreate your ear's normal antibacterial state. Apply these as you did the other ear drops.

steps.title: Take oral antibiotics.
steps.content: Take oral antibiotics. If your ear infection is more severe, especially if it's moved beyond the ear, you will need to take antibiotics by mouth. [16] X Trustworthy Source MedlinePlus Collection of medical information sourced from the US National Library of Medicine Go to source Finish the entire course of antibiotics. You should begin to feel better 36 to 48 hours after starting treatment, and completely better in 6 days. Some infections are caused by fungus instead of bacteria. In that case, you'll need to take antifungal pills rather than antibiotics. [17] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source If you are immunocompetent, Having a normal immune response topical treatment is favored over oral treatment.

steps.title: Ask about corticosteroids.
steps.content: Ask about corticosteroids. If your ear is inflamed, you may need to have a round of corticosteroids to help. They can also help if itching is bothering you. [18] X Trustworthy Source MedlinePlus Collection of medical information sourced from the US National Library of Medicine Go to source

steps.title: Dry your ears thoroughly after swimming to prevent infections.
steps.content: Dry your ears thoroughly after swimming to prevent infections. When you get out of the swimming pool, use a towel to dry your ears thoroughly. These infections thrive in moist environments, so drying out your ear can help prevent infection. [19] X Research source Skip the cotton-tipped swabs, though, as these can increase your chances of contracting the infection.

steps.title: Put in ear plugs.
steps.content: Put in ear plugs. Before swimming, put ear plugs in your ears. Ear plugs will help keep your ears dry while swimming. [20] X Trustworthy Source Centers for Disease Control and Prevention Main public health institute for the US, run by the Dept. of Health and Human Services Go to source

steps.title: Use a treatment after swimming.
steps.content: Use a treatment after swimming. Mix 1 part vinegar to 1 part rubbing alcohol. Drop about a teaspoon into your ear. Tilt your head so it pours back out. [21] X Research source Check with your doctor before using this solution, as it is not recommended for people with punctured eardrums. You can also apply the mixture before swimming. The purpose is to keep you ear as dry as possible and as free of bacteria as possible.

steps.title: Don't swim in dirty water.
steps.content: Don't swim in dirty water. If the water at the swimming pool looks murky or dirty, don't get in it. Also, skip swimming in lakes or the ocean. [22] X Research source

steps.title: Keep your ears free of products.
steps.content: Keep your ears free of products. If you spray on hair spray or use hair dye, put cotton in your ears first. These products can irritate your ears, so protecting your ears against them can reduce your chances of outer ear infections. [23] X Research source

steps.title: Skip ear candles.
steps.content: Skip ear candles. While may be tempting to try to unblock your ear with an ear candle, they actually do not help all that much. Plus, they can severely damage your ear. [24] X Research source

steps.title: Notice itching.
steps.content: Notice itching. Itching, mild or more severe, can be an indication that you have an outer ear infection. [25] X Expert Source Monica Kieu, DO, FACS Board Certified Otolaryngologist Expert Interview. 20 October 2020. You may itch inside your ear or along the outside. However, a slight itch doesn't automatically mean you have an outer ear infection. [26] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source

steps.title: Look for drainage.
steps.content: Look for drainage. Any kind of drainage from the ear can indicate an ear infection. However, look for drainage with color--yellow, green, or white. Also, if the drainage smells bad, that could also indicate an ear infection. [27] X Expert Source Monica Kieu, DO, FACS Board Certified Otolaryngologist Expert Interview. 20 October 2020.

steps.title: Pay attention to pain.
steps.content: Pay attention to pain. If you have pain in your ear, it could indicate an ear infection. If you press on your ear and the pain worsens, that's even more likely to be an indicator of an ear infection. [28] X Expert Source Monica Kieu, DO, FACS Board Certified Otolaryngologist Expert Interview. 20 October 2020. In severe cases, pain may begin spreading across your face, which means you need to get to a doctor immediately, as the infection is spreading. [29] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source

steps.title: Check for redness.
steps.content: Check for redness. Look at your ear closely in a mirror. If you can see some redness, that may also indicate an ear infection. [30] X Trustworthy Source Centers for Disease Control and Prevention Main public health institute for the US, run by the Dept. of Health and Human Services Go to source

steps.title: Notice hearing loss.
steps.content: Notice hearing loss. Hearing loss is a more advanced symptom of ear infections, so if you begin to notice your hearing going in an ear along with other symptoms, that is definitely a reason to see a doctor. [31] X Trustworthy Source Johns Hopkins Medicine Official resource database of the world-leading Johns Hopkins Hospital Go to source At its most advanced stage, your ear canal will be blocked completely. [32] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source

steps.title: Look for the advanced symptoms.
steps.content: Look for the advanced symptoms. If your ear or lymph nodes swell, that is a far progression of an ear infection. Another advanced symptom is a fever. [33] X Research source
